AAdvises son onlyPartial (no patient disclosure)DelayedIncomplete
BWithholds diagnosisNoDelayedUnethical
CDirectly informs patientYesPromptEvidence‐based
DEthics consult firstIndirectDelayedUnnecessary in clear‐capacity case

Clinical Pearls

- Always assess decision‐making capacity; ALS patients often remain cognitively intact, but screen for FTD features.
• Use structured protocols (SPIKES) to deliver bad news: Setting, Perception, Invitation, Knowledge, Emotions, Summary/Strategy.
• Early disclosure facilitates planning for respiratory support, feeding options, and palliative care involvement.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating family wishes with patient wishes, leading to nondisclosure.
2. Over‐utilizing ethics committees for routine disclosures, causing harmful delays.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Medical Association, Code of Medical Ethics Opinion 1.1.1 (2024): “Physicians should disclose diagnoses honestly to capacitated patients.” (Level V expert opinion)
2. American Academy of Neurology Practice Guideline for ALS (2019): “Clinicians should provide patients with a timely diagnosis discussion, including prognosis and management options.” (Level B evidence)

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Decision‐making capacity relies on intact prefrontal cortex networks (dorsolateral and orbitofrontal circuits). In ALS‐FTD overlap, degeneration of these regions may impair appreciation and reasoning, necessitating formal capacity assessment.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2021 exam. Ethical dilemmas involving disclosure and patient autonomy are frequently tested in multiple‐choice format; expect scenarios with family requests for nondisclosure and capacity assessments.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is A. Tell the son that his father has the right to know about his condition.. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

question_text: In a patient with Wernicke's aphasia, which of the following symptoms is most commonly observed?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Part 2 2020] Wernicke’s aphasia results from lesions in the dominant (usually left) posterior superior temporal gyrus (Brodmann area 22), disrupting the ventral language-processing stream. Patients exhibit fluent, grammatically correct speech riddled with paraphasias, neologisms and jargon, yet have severely impaired auditory and reading comprehension. Because the lesion disconnects the auditory word-form area from semantic memory, repetition is also typically defective. By contrast, Broca’s aphasia (inferior frontal gyrus lesion) causes nonfluent, effortful speech with preserved comprehension, and conduction aphasia (arcuate fasciculus lesion) presents with impaired repetition despite good comprehension.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Option A encapsulates the core clinical syndrome of Wernicke’s aphasia. Lesion mapping studies (Dronkers et al., 2007, Brain) consistently localize impaired semantic processing and fluent paraphasic output to the left posterior superior temporal cortex. The Boston Diagnostic Aphasia Examination (Goodglass & Kaplan, 1983) defines Wernicke’s by a Fluency score ≥8 (logorrhea, neologisms), Auditory Comprehension score ≤3, and Repetition score ≤3. A Cochrane review (Brady et al., 2016) affirmed that poor comprehension distinguishes Wernicke’s from other fluent aphasias. Damage to Wernicke’s area also disrupts connections in the arcuate fasciculus, compounding repetition deficits. In contrast, Broca’s aphasia shows effortful speech with intact comprehension (Option B), conduction aphasia spares comprehension but severely impairs repetition (Option C), and motor pathway lesions produce weakness or ataxia without primary language dysfunction (Option D).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Nonfluent, effortful speech with good comprehension
• Represents Broca’s aphasia (inferior frontal lesion).
• Misconception: equating fluency with comprehension—Broca’s patients understand language but cannot produce it.
• Differentiator: speech production is telegraphic, agrammatic.

C. Difficulty in repeating words despite intact comprehension
• Characteristic of conduction aphasia (arcuate fasciculus lesion).
• Misconception: any repetition deficit implies Wernicke’s—however, Wernicke’s also has comprehension deficits, whereas conduction aphasics comprehend well.
• Differentiator: spontaneous speech in conduction aphasia is fluent and meaningful.

D. Loss of motor coordination and muscle weakness
• Reflects a motor pathway or cerebellar lesion, not a primary language disorder.
• Misconception: conflating “aphasia” with “apraxia” or “ataxia.”
• Differentiator: motor findings accompany strength or coordination deficits, not pure language disturbance.

Comparison Table

FeatureWernicke’s Aphasia (A)Broca’s Aphasia (B)Conduction Aphasia (C)Motor Deficit (D)
Speech FluencyFluent, logorrhea, paraphasiasNonfluent, telegraphicFluent, paraphasicN/A
Auditory ComprehensionSeverely impairedLargely intactLargely intactIntact (language not primarily affected)
RepetitionImpaired (due to arcuate fasciculus)Impaired (due to motor planning)Severely impairedIntact
Lesion LocationPosterior superior temporal gyrusInferior frontal gyrus (Broca’s)Arcuate fasciculusMotor cortex, corticospinal tracts, cerebellum

Clinical Pearls

- Always assess fluency, comprehension, and repetition systematically; the “triple test” rapidly classifies aphasia subtypes.
• Wernicke’s aphasia patients often lack awareness of their deficits (anosognosia), making bedside correction challenging.
• In acute stroke, early identification of Wernicke’s syndrome on MRI DWI can guide prognostication and targeted speech therapy.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating “fluent” speech with “intact” speech—Wernicke’s aphasic speech is fluent but semantically empty.
2. Assuming repetition deficits are exclusive to Wernicke’s aphasia—in reality, conduction aphasia features a more isolated repetition impairment.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (AHA/ASA) 2021 Guidelines on Post-Stroke Rehabilitation: Class I recommendation for early (within 48 hours) comprehensive language assessment and initiation of evidence-based speech and language therapy (Level of Evidence A).
2. National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) 2019 Stroke Rehabilitation Guidelines: Strong recommendation for at least 45 minutes of speech and language therapy daily, five days per week, shown in RCTs to improve functional communication (moderate-quality evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Wernicke’s area resides in the posterior superior temporal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere. It interfaces with the middle temporal gyrus (semantic lexicon) and projects via the arcuate fasciculus to the inferior frontal gyrus (speech production). Lesions disrupt the ventral stream (“what” pathway) for mapping sounds to meaning.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Ischemic or hemorrhagic injury to Wernicke’s cortex abolishes phonological-to-semantic integration, leading to an inability to decode incoming speech. The resulting lack of meaningful auditory input prevents normal lexical retrieval, yielding paraphasic, neologistic output.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Quick language screen: assess spontaneous speech for fluency and paraphasias.
2. Test comprehension: follow multistep commands, answer yes/no questions.
3. Evaluate repetition: single words, sentences.
4. Localize lesion: obtain MRI with diffusion-weighted imaging.
5. Formal speech–language pathology evaluation for therapy planning.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- Acute infarcts in Wernicke’s area appear as focal DWI hyperintensities in the posterior superior temporal lobe.
• CT may initially miss small cortical strokes; MRI is preferred for detailed mapping.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Part 2 2020 exam.
Aphasia classification by fluency, comprehension and repetition is a high-yield topic, frequently tested in both standalone vignettes and integrated stroke/neurolocalization questions.

question_text: A 60-year-old male patient had visual loss and denied it. Upon examination, he had a visual field defect. What is the diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2021] Visual anosognosia (Anton syndrome) is a denial of cortical blindness despite intact anterior visual pathways and objective evidence of visual loss. Key concepts:
• Neuroanatomy of vision: primary visual cortex (V1) in the occipital lobes and visual association cortices.
• Anosognosia: failure to recognize neurologic deficits due to disruption of self-monitoring networks (occipito-parietal–frontal connections).
• Cortical blindness: bilateral V1 lesions produce visual field deficits; patients confabulate descriptions of visual scenes they cannot see.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Visual anosognosia arises when bilateral occipital lobe damage abolishes visual input to V1, and disruption of parieto-frontal monitoring pathways prevents awareness of the loss. Anton’s original 1899 description and subsequent case series (Bisiach et al., 1979; Anton, 1914) confirm denial plus confabulation as hallmark features. Modern neuroimaging (MRI, DWI) localizes lesions to V1 and adjacent extrastriate areas; functional PET studies show hypometabolism in fronto-parietal networks (Karnath et al., 2005). No current guidelines address this rare syndrome specifically, but AHA/ASA stroke protocols emphasize bilateral occipital infarct recognition. The patient’s denial of blindness despite documented visual field defects is pathognomonic for visual anosognosia.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Acalculia
– Incorrect: Disorder of numerical calculation due to left inferior parietal (angular gyrus) damage. No denial of visual loss.
– Misconception: Confusing cortical deficits generally with anosognosia.

B. Agraphia
– Incorrect: Loss of writing ability from superior parietal or Exner’s area involvement; no visual denial.
– Misconception: Assuming any “-graphia” implies visual unawareness.

C. Optic ataxia
– Incorrect: Impaired visually guided reaching from dorsal stream (parietal) lesions; patients appreciate visual status but cannot coordinate movements.
– Misconception: Equating any visuomotor deficit with visual unawareness.

Comparison Table

FeatureVisual AnosognosiaAcalculiaAgraphiaOptic Ataxia
Core deficitDenial of visual lossCalculation impairmentWriting impairmentVisuomotor coordination loss
Lesion locationBilateral occipital lobesLeft inferior parietal lobuleLeft superior parietal/Exner’s areaDorsal parietal stream
Awareness of deficitAbsent (denial)PresentPresentPresent
ConfabulationCommonAbsentAbsentAbsent

Clinical Pearls

1. Anton syndrome follows bilateral occipital infarctions—ask about visual denial even if patients claim normal sight.
2. Differentiate from visual neglect: neglect patients acknowledge vision but fail to attend to one side.
3. Confabulation (e.g., describing scenery) is a key distinguishing feature, not seen in malingering.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Mistaking visual neglect for anosognosia—neglect patients know they can’t attend to stimuli, anosognosic patients deny any deficit.
2. Overlooking confabulation: failure to probe for spontaneous fabrications leads to misdiagnosis.

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Visual anosognosia requires bilateral destruction of V1 (calcarine cortex) and disconnection of occipito-parietal association fibers from prefrontal self-monitoring regions. The splenium of the corpus callosum may also be implicated, preventing interhemispheric integration.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT/MRI: bilateral occipital hypodensities on non-contrast head CT; MRI DWI shows acute infarcts in the calcarine fissures.
• PET/SPECT: hypometabolism in parieto-frontal networks associated with self-awareness.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2021 exam. Visual anosognosia is frequently tested in neurology boards under cortical blindness and denial-of-deficit syndromes, often via clinical vignettes requiring recognition of “denial of blindness with field defects.”

question_text: An elderly patient presented with a visual field defect but denied having left homonymous hemianopia. A CT brain scan was performed. What is the explanation for her issue?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2022] Anosognosia is a neurological syndrome in which patients lack awareness of their deficits despite clear clinical evidence. Homonymous hemianopia results from post‐chiasmal lesions—most commonly occipital lobe infarction. Visual anosognosia (“Anton syndrome”) occurs when bilateral or extensive occipital damage disrupts both visual processing (Brodmann areas 17–18) and error‐monitoring networks (parietal–frontal circuits), leading to denial of blindness or hemianopia often with confabulation. This must be distinguished from visual neglect (an attentional deficit due to parietal lobe lesions), apraxia (impaired motor planning), and psychiatric denial (motivated psychological refusal to acknowledge deficits).

Evidence-Based Analysis

Visual anosognosia is well characterized in Anton syndrome, first described by Gabriel Anton (1899) and detailed in Bisiach et al. (1986). Patients produce confabulations to “fill in” missing visual input. Neuroimaging (MRI DWI) in Anton syndrome reveals bilateral occipital infarcts disrupting V1/V2 and disconnection from self‐monitoring networks (insula, medial prefrontal cortex). The 2019 AHA/ASA Stroke Guidelines recommend systematic neuropsychological screening—including awareness deficits—after ischemic stroke (Class IIa, Level C). CT has limited sensitivity for cortical infarcts, especially in the posterior circulation; MRI is superior for detecting early ischemia. In contrast, visual neglect stems from right inferior parietal lobule damage and presents with inattention rather than denial of vision loss.

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Psychiatric
– Incorrect because denial is due to cortical lesion, not volitional or psychodynamic refusal. Psychiatric denial lacks the specific pattern of field testing failure and confabulation.

C. Apraxia
– Refers to impaired motor planning with intact strength and sensation; does not affect visual fields or awareness of vision.

D. Visual neglect
– An attentional disorder from parietal lobe lesions leading to inattention to one hemifield; patients may still acknowledge visual testing failure when confronted, unlike anosognosia where they deny any deficit.

Comparison Table

FeatureVisual AnosognosiaVisual NeglectApraxiaPsychiatric Denial
Core deficitDenial of field lossInattention to one sideImpaired motor planningPsychological refusal
Lesion locationOccipital cortex ± self‐awareness networkRight inferior parietal lobuleFrontal (premotor) or parietalNo focal lesion
Awareness during testingDenies defect, confabulatesOften unaware until provokedAware of vision, cannot moveVariable insight
Imaging findingsBilateral/posterior cortical infarcts (MRI)Parietal lobe infarctNo direct visual findingsNormal structural imaging

Clinical Pearls

- Anton syndrome (visual anosognosia) classically follows bilateral PCA strokes; unilateral lesions may also produce field‐specific anosognosia.
• CT may appear normal in acute cortical infarcts; MRI DWI is the gold standard for early detection of occipital lesions.
• Formal perimetry is essential to document hemianopia and distinguish denial from inattention.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Conflating visual neglect with anosognosia—neglect is an attentional disorder, not denial of vision loss.
2. Attributing denial to malingering or psychiatric causes without considering underlying cortical lesions.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. American Heart Association/American Stroke Association (2019). “Guidelines for the Early Management of Patients With Acute Ischemic Stroke” recommend cognitive and awareness screening post‐stroke (Class IIa, Level C).
2. European Stroke Organisation–ESMINT (2023). “Management of Posterior Circulation Stroke” endorses MRI DWI over CT for early detection of occipital infarcts (Level B evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Lesions in primary visual cortex (BA17) produce contralateral homonymous hemianopia. Disconnection of occipital areas from parietal–frontal self‐monitoring circuits (insula, medial prefrontal cortex) underlies anosognosia and confabulation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Damage to feedforward visual pathways prevents conscious perception; simultaneous disruption of feedback/error‐detection networks prevents recognition of the deficit, leading to denial and confabulation.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Bedside confrontation testing to identify hemianopia.
2. Formal automated perimetry to quantify field loss.
3. CT to exclude hemorrhage (may be normal).
4. MRI DWI for definitive detection of occipital infarcts.
5. Neuropsychological assessment for awareness deficits.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- CT sensitivity for acute posterior cortical infarcts is <60% within the first 24 hours.
• MRI DWI approaches >95% sensitivity for early ischemic changes in the occipital lobes.

Board Examination Focus

Visual anosognosia is frequently tested as a vignette of denial of field loss despite objective hemianopia on testing. This question appeared in Promotion 2022 exam. Students should recognize Anton syndrome versus neglect or malingering and know appropriate imaging modalities.

question_text: A soldier who was driving a military tank that exploded has some injuries, but two of his friends died. He dreams at night, feels guilt, and wishes to leave the army. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2019] Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) is a trauma‐and‐stress‐related disorder triggered by exposure to death, serious injury or sexual violence. Key DSM-5 domains include intrusion (e.g., nightmares, flashbacks), avoidance, negative alterations in cognition/mood (e.g., guilt) and hyperarousal. Adjustment disorder entails maladaptive emotional or behavioral symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor but lacks core intrusion or arousal features. Acute depressive reactions may follow stress but do not involve re-experiencing trauma. Psychotic disorders are defined by hallucinations/delusions without necessarily having a precipitating stressor. Timeline is crucial: PTSD requires symptoms persisting beyond one month after the event; adjustment disorder symptoms begin within three months and resolve by six months if the stressor or its consequences cease.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Psychosis
• Lacks core features: no hallucinations/delusions or thought‐disorder.
• Misconception: trauma always induces psychosis – psychotic symptoms are not intrusion phenomena.

B. Acute depression
• Depressed mood alone does not explain re‐experiencing or avoidance.
• Misconception: guilt post‐trauma equals depressive disorder – in PTSD, guilt is trauma‐related, not pervasive low mood.

C. Adjustment disorder
• Absence of intrusion (nightmares) and arousal features.
• Misconception: any stressor‐related distress = adjustment disorder – full PTSD symptom clusters must be assessed.

Comparison Table

FeatureAdjustment DisorderPTSD
TriggerAny psychosocial stressorCriterion A trauma (death/injury threat)
Timeline<3 months onset, resolves by 6 m≥1 month duration
Intrusion (nightmares)AbsentPresent
AvoidanceMay avoid stressorActive avoidance of trauma reminders
Cognition/Mood alterationsDistress/disproportionate worryNegative beliefs, survivor’s guilt
Arousal/reactivityNot prominentHypervigilance, startle response

Clinical Pearls

1. Nightmares and flashbacks are pathognomonic for PTSD, not adjustment disorder.
2. Survivor’s guilt is a hallmark negative cognition in PTSD – assess with PCL-5 screening.
3. Early trauma‐focused CBT within months reduces chronic PTSD risk (Ehlers et al., 2014).

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating any post‐stress guilt with depressive disorder rather than PTSD’s negative cognition domain.
2. Misdiagnosing acute stress disorder (<1 month) as PTSD without verifying duration criterion.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. VA/DoD Clinical Practice Guideline for PTSD (2017): Recommends first‐line TF‐CBT and SSRIs (Level A evidence).
2. NICE NG116 (2018): Endorses EMDR and TF-CBT as frontline; avoid pharmacotherapy monotherapy except when therapy unavailable (moderate evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Amygdala hyperactivation drives fear conditioning; hippocampal atrophy impairs contextual memory, perpetuating intrusive recollections; prefrontal cortex hypofunction reduces top-down regulation.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

PTSD arises from maladaptive consolidation of traumatic memories via glutamatergic overactivity in amygdala, dysregulated HPA axis (cortisol alterations), and impaired extinction learning.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Elicit trauma history (DSM-5 Criterion A).
2. Screen with PCL-5 or CAPS-5.
3. Verify intrusion, avoidance, negative cognition, arousal clusters.
4. Confirm symptom duration ≥1 month.
5. Exclude other psychiatric/medical causes.

Neuroimaging Pearls

Chronic PTSD often shows reduced hippocampal volume on MRI and increased amygdala activation on functional imaging (fMRI paradigms).

Pharmacotherapy Focus

First‐line: Sertraline 50–200 mg/day or paroxetine 20–50 mg/day for at least 12 weeks. Augmentation with prazosin for trauma‐related nightmares (low‐dose).

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2019 exam. PTSD is frequently tested by presenting re‐experiencing, avoidance, negative mood and arousal symptoms following a Criterion A event, emphasizing timeline and core DSM-5 domains.

Evidence-Based Analysis

The correct answer is C. Adjustment disorder. This is supported by current clinical evidence and practice guidelines.

question_text: In Balint syndrome, which one of these clinical pictures is one of the presentations?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2018] Balint syndrome is a higher‐order visuospatial disorder resulting from bilateral parieto‐occipital lesions. Key components:
• Dorsal visual stream (“where” pathway) disruption, impairing spatial attention.
• Simultagnosia: inability to perceive more than one object at a time.
• Optic ataxia: misreaching for objects under visual guidance.
• Ocular apraxia: failure to initiate voluntary gaze shifts despite intact cranial nerves.

This constellation results in classic triad without primary visual field cut or agnosia for object identity.

Evidence-Based Analysis

Simultagnosia is the hallmark of Balint syndrome and reflects dorsal stream dysfunction in the bilateral superior parietal lobules (Rizzo et al., Neurology 2000). Functional MRI and lesion studies (Levine et al., Brain 1990) localize simultanagnosia to the intersection of the parietal and occipital lobes, impairing global scene perception while preserving object recognition (Goodale & Milner, 1992). Current stroke guidelines (AHA/ASA 2019) emphasize early MRI-DWI for posterior circulation infarcts to detect bilateral parieto-occipital ischemia, the most common etiology. Rehabilitation focuses on environmental cueing and compensatory scanning techniques (American Congress of Rehabilitation Medicine, 2021).

Incorrect Options Analysis

B. Acalculia
• Incorrect: Acalculia is a disturbance of numerical processing due to dominant inferior parietal damage, not dorsal stream lesions.
• Misconception: Confusing general parietal signs with specific visuospatial deficits.

C. Vivid hallucination
• Incorrect: Complex visual hallucinations occur in Charles Bonnet syndrome (isolated occipital lesions) or Lewy body dementia, not in Balint syndrome’s pure visuospatial disorder.
• Differentiator: Hallucinations imply preserved primary vision but aberrant visual imagery.

D. Oculomotor apraxia
• Incorrect in this context: Balint’s “ocular apraxia” refers to inability to voluntarily shift gaze in response to visual stimuli, whereas “oculomotor apraxia” commonly denotes congenital saccadic initiation failure (e.g., ataxia telangiectasia).
• Misconception: Terminology overlap between ocular and oculomotor apraxia.

Comparison Table

FeatureSimultagnosia (Correct)AcalculiaVivid HallucinationOculomotor Apraxia
Underlying lesionBilateral superior parietal‐occipitalDominant inferior parietalOccipital cortex, visual areasCongenital or PSP (brainstem)
Core deficitGlobal visual integrationNumerical computationPerceptual phenomenaSaccade initiation
Clinical presentationSees only one object in fieldCannot perform calculationsComplex formed images seenCannot initiate voluntary saccades
Relation to Balint syndromePart of triadNot partNot partDifferent entity

Clinical Pearls

- Simultagnosia can be screened by asking patients to describe a scene; they will name objects one at a time without global context.
• Optic ataxia and ocular apraxia often co-exist; testing requires pointing to peripheral targets and instructing voluntary gaze shifts without head movement.
• Early recognition of Balint syndrome guides targeted neurorehabilitation strategies to improve visual scanning.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

1. Equating Balint syndrome with visual agnosia; object recognition remains intact in Balint’s.
2. Confusing ocular apraxia (visual scanning) with oculomotor apraxia (saccadic generation failure) seen in progressive supranuclear palsy.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

- AHA/ASA 2019 Guidelines for Early Management of Acute Ischemic Stroke: recommend MRI-DWI within 6 hours for posterior circulation syndromes (Class I, Level A).
• Canadian Stroke Best Practice Guidelines 2020: endorse multidisciplinary rehabilitation including visuospatial training for higher‐order visual deficits post‐stroke (Level II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Balint syndrome arises from lesions in the bilateral superior parietal lobules and adjacent occipital cortices, disrupting the dorsal stream pathways that mediate spatial attention and visuomotor integration.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Bilateral dorsal stream injury abolishes the brain’s ability to integrate spatial arrays, preventing simultaneous object perception (simultagnosia), accurate visuomotor coordination (optic ataxia), and deliberate gaze shifts (ocular apraxia).

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Clinical screening: ask naming of multi‐object scenes.
2. Visuomotor tests: reach for peripheral targets under vision.
3. Eye movement assessment: voluntary saccade initiation.
4. Neuroimaging: MRI with DWI to confirm bilateral parieto‐occipital infarcts.

Neuroimaging Pearls

MRI-DWI often reveals symmetrical or watershed infarcts in the posterior cerebral artery territories bilaterally, correlating with clinical triad severity.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2018 exam. Balint syndrome triad (simultagnosia, optic ataxia, ocular apraxia) is a frequently tested topic in behavioral neurology sections.

question_text: A patient presents with a right occipital lesion and visual field defect. What condition could be associated with this finding?
explanation:
Conceptual Framework & Clinical Context

[Exam: Promotion 2023] Unilateral occipital lobe lesions classically disrupt the primary visual cortex (Brodmann area 17) representation of the contralateral visual field. Key concepts:
• Retinotopic organization: The calcarine fissure divides upper (cuneus) and lower (lingual gyrus) visual field representations.
• Blood supply: Posterior cerebral artery infarcts commonly underlie isolated occipital lesions with macular sparing if collateral MCA perfusion is preserved.
• Higher-order visual syndromes (e.g., visual anosognosia, optic ataxia) require bilateral dorsal or ventral association area involvement and are not produced by a unilateral occipital focus.

(120 words)

Evidence-Based Analysis

Hemianopia is the loss of one half of the visual field in both eyes, typically resulting from lesions of the optic radiations or primary visual cortex. A right occipital cortical lesion interrupts fibers subserving the left visual hemifield, producing a left homonymous hemianopia. Population studies estimate that up to 70% of posterior cerebral artery infarcts present with homonymous field defects (Plant et al., 2019). The American Academy of Neurology Practice Parameter (2006) mandates formal perimetry to document and characterize homonymous field loss (Level A evidence). By contrast, visual anosognosia (Anton syndrome) arises only after bilateral occipital destruction, leading to cortical blindness with denial of deficit (Biousse & Newman, 2010). Optic ataxia reflects parietal lobe damage to the dorsal stream, impairing visually guided reaching (Milner & Goodale, 2006). Vitamin B6 sensory ganglionopathy is a peripheral neuropathy unrelated to cortical lesions.

Incorrect Options Analysis

A. Visual anosognosia
– Incorrect: Requires bilateral occipital cortex involvement; unilateral lesions produce field loss without denial.
– Misconception: Denial of blindness equals hemianopia.
– Differentiator: Anosognosia patients are cortically blind yet insist vision is intact.

B. Optic ataxia
– Incorrect: Manifests as misreaching under visual guidance due to bilateral parietal (dorsal stream) lesions.
– Misconception: Any occipital lesion causes visuomotor deficits.
– Differentiator: Optic ataxia shows normal visual fields but poor hand-eye coordination.

C. Vitamin B6 sensory ganglionopathy
– Incorrect: A metabolic peripheral sensory neuronopathy, sparing central visual pathways.
– Misconception: Nutritional deficiencies mimic cortical visual loss.
– Differentiator: Presents with distal sensory loss, not visual field defects.

Comparison Table

FeatureHemianopiaVisual AnosognosiaOptic AtaxiaVit B6 Sensory Ganglionopathy
Lesion locationUnilateral occipital cortex (V1)Bilateral occipital cortexBilateral parietal association areasDorsal root ganglia
Visual field involvementContralateral half-field lossCortical blindness (full-field)Intact fieldsIntact fields
Clinical presentationContralateral homonymous defectDenial of vision lossMisreaching, optic grasp reflex lossDistal sensory (vibration, position)
Blood supplyPCA territoryBilateral PCABilateral parietal branchesSystemic metabolic

Clinical Pearls

- Macular sparing in occipital infarcts suggests collateral MCA supply to the occipital pole.
• Confrontation visual field testing is 80–90% sensitive; confirm with automated perimetry.
• Homonymous hemianopia often delays rehabilitation in stroke; early detection guides visual field restitution therapies.

Common Pitfalls and Misconceptions

- Confusing visual neglect (parietal damage) with hemianopia; neglect patients may track moving objects into a blind field.
• Assuming denial of vision loss (anosognosia) can occur with a unilateral lesion; remember Anton syndrome is bilateral.

Latest Guidelines and Trials

1. European Academy of Neurology (EAN) Guideline on Visual Field Defects in Stroke, 2017: recommends standardized perimetry within 2 weeks of stroke onset (Grade B).
2. AAN Quality Standards Subcommittee Practice Parameter for Homonymous Visual Field Loss, 2006: endorses formal visual field measurement (Level A evidence).
3. RESTORE Trial (Randomized Study of Visual Restoration Therapy), 2022: demonstrated modest improvement in border awareness in chronic hemianopia (Class II evidence).

Neuroanatomical Correlations

Primary visual fibers from the lateral geniculate nucleus project to V1 along the calcarine fissure. Upper quadrantic fibers traverse the cuneus; lower fibers course via the lingual gyrus. A lesion in the right calcarine cortex spares the macula if dual PCA–MCA supply persists, producing a classic left homonymous hemianopia with or without macular sparing.

Pathophysiology Breakdown

Occlusion of the PCA leads to ischemia of the striate cortex. Neuronal death in V1 disrupts transmission of the left hemifield visual input from both eyes, while ventral and dorsal association streams (for object recognition and visuomotor coordination) remain intact unless adjacent watershed areas are involved.

Diagnostic Algorithm

1. Obtain history: onset, associated neuro deficits.
2. Perform bedside confrontation fields.
3. Order formal automated perimetry (e.g., Humphrey).
4. Neuroimaging: MRI brain with DWI/FLAIR to localize occipital infarct.
5. Vascular imaging: MRA/CTA to assess PCA patency.
6. Initiate visual rehabilitation and manage vascular risk factors.

Neuroimaging Pearls

- MRI DWI: hyperintense lesion in occipital cortex confirms acute infarction.
• T2/FLAIR sequences demonstrate chronic gliosis in PCA territory.
• CT may miss small cortical infarcts; MRI is preferred for definitive localization.

Board Examination Focus

This question appeared in Promotion 2023 exam.
On neurology boards, homonymous hemianopia due to occipital lobe lesions is frequently tested as a classic V1 deficit; students should distinguish it from higher-order visual syndromes requiring bilateral cortical involvement.
